titleStmt.title: Information measures for hesitant fuzzy sets and interval-valued hesitant fuzzy sets

affiliation.orgName: Quchan Institute of Engineering and Technology

analytic.title: Information measures for hesitant fuzzy sets and interval-valued hesitant fuzzy sets

biblStruct.note: Received 17 September 2012 Received in revised form 12 March 2013 Accepted 18 March 2013

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Hesitant fuzzy set Interval-valued hesitant fuzzy set Entropy Similarity measure Distance measure Clustering algorithm 2 INS 10018 No. of Pages 16

div.p: The main purpose of this paper is to investigate the relationship between the entropy, the 27 similarity measure and the distance measure for hesitant fuzzy sets (HFSs) and interval-28 valued hesitant fuzzy sets (IVHFSs). The primary goal of the study is to suggest the system-29 atic transformation of the entropy into the similarity measure for HFSs and vice versa. 30 Achieving this goal is important to the task of introducing new formulas for the entropy 31 and the similarity measure of HFSs. With results having been obtained for HFSs, similar 32 results are also obtainable for IVHFSs. This paper also discusses the need for proposing a 33 new entropy for HFSs and subsequently a new similarity measure for HFSs. Finally, two 34 clustering algorithms are developed under a hesitant fuzzy environment in which indices 35 of similarity measures of HFSs and IVHFSs are applied in data analysis and classification. 36 Moreover, two practical examples are examined to compare the proposed methods with 37 the existing ones.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In fuzzy set (FS) theory, which is a generalization of classical set theory introduced by Zadeh [38], entropy, distance measure and similarity measure have drawn the attention of many researchers who have studied these three concepts from different points of view. Similarity and distance measures have been widely applied in many fields such as multicriteria decision-making [5,21], group decision [27,33], grey relational analysis [26], pattern recognition [11,14], image processing [15], and cluster analysis [37]. Since the similarity and distance measures of FSs and their extensions [21,39] have been applied to many real-world situations, the entropy measure [1,3,10] can be naturally applied to such fields due to its close relationship with similarity measure and distance measure. In recent years, Torra [22] introduced the concept of hesitant fuzzy set (HFS) as an extension of FS in which the membership degree of a given element, called the hesitant fuzzy element (HFE), is defined as a set of possible values. This situation can be found in a group decision making problem. To clarify the necessity of introducing HFSs, consider a situation in which two decision makers discuss the membership degree of an element x to a set A, one wants to assign 0.2, but the other 0.4. Accordingly, the difficulty of establishing a common membership degree is not because there is a margin of error (as in intuitionistic fuzzy sets), or some possibility distribution values (as in type-2 fuzzy sets), but because there is a set of possible values. HFSs can be applied in many decision making problems (see [25,29,44]). Later, a number of other extensions of the HFSs have been developed such as dual hesitant fuzzy sets (DHFSs) [43], generalized hesitant fuzzy sets (GHFSs) [16] and hesitant fuzzy linguistic term sets (HFLTSs) [17].

A growing number of studies focus on the distance measure, the similarity measure and the entropy for the concepts of FSs [38], intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IFSs) [1] and interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IVIFSs) [25,26]. Distance measures are fundamentally important in various fields such as decision making, market prediction, and pattern recognition. The most

div.p: The idea of Definition 2.5 goes back to Zhang et al. [42], who introduced entropies of IVFSs based on the intuitionistic distance.
According to Definition 2.5, one can construct a variety of entropies for HFSs by using various distances for HFSs.

Recently, Xu and Xia [35] have investigated some distance measures for HFSs drawing on the well-known Hamming distance, the Euclidean distance, the Hausdorff metric and their generalizations. They have also given a variety of ordered weighted distance measures for HFSs in which the distances are rearranged in decreasing order.

div.head: Relationship between information measures for HFSs
div.p: Throughout this section, we investigate the relationship between the distance, the similarity measure and the entropy for HFSs based on their axiomatic definitions. In order to put forward some new formulas, a sequence of theorems are provided on how the mentioned information measures for HFSs can be transformed by each other.

div.head: Transformation of the distance into the similarity measure for HFSs
div.p: This section will describe a method that constructs a family of similarity measures for HFSs using a distance between HFSs.
Theorem
div.formula: Z(t) = 1 À t; (2) ZðtÞ ¼ 1Àt 1þt ; (3) Z(t) = 1 À t e tÀ1 ; (4) Z(t) = 1 À t 2 .

div.p: This section will describe a method that creates a family of entropies for HFSs using a distance between HFSs.

div.head: Transformation of the similarity measure into the entropy for HFSs
div.p: This section will describe a method that generates a family of entropies for HFSs using a similarity measure for HFSs.
By taking Theorems 3.3.1 and 3.2.1 into account, the following theorem is obtained.

div.p: This section describes a method that produces a family of similarity measures for HFSs using an entropy for HFSs.

div.head: The importance of the proposed entropies for HFSs
div.p: In this section, some illustrative examples are provided to indicate that the family of entropies introduced by Xu and Xia [36] does not distinguish different HFEs correctly in some cases. Comparison results show that the proposed entropies for HFEs are more reasonable in distinguishing than the entropies proposed by Xu and Xia [36].

Note that Xu and Xia's method [36] cannot efficiently deal with the hesitant fuzzy element distinguishing problems when different HFEs are equal with their complements. That is, applying the family of entropies proposed by Xu and Xia [36] which yields a consistent and accurate outcome.

It should be pointed out that if the other eighteen entropy formulas of Xu and Xia, which are given by the relations ( 17)- (34) in [36] and called entropy formulas based on the similarity measures, are applied to HFEs h 1 (x) = {0.1, 0.5, 0.9} and h 2 (x) = {0.4, 0.5, 0.6}, then the degree of eighteen entropy formulas based on the similarity measures equals one, which is also unreasonable.
It is possible to give many such examples. Let h 1 (x) = {0.2, 0.5, 0.8}, h 2 (x) = {0.25, 0.5, 0.75}, h 3 (x) = {0.3, 0.5, 0.7} be three
HFEs. Then, one gets

, although the fuzziness degree of h 1 (x) is not equal to those of h 2 (x) and h 3 (x). In other words, there are many cases in which all entropy formulas of Xu and Xia [36] cannot distinguish between quite different situations.

div.head: Information measures for interval-valued hesitant fuzzy sets
div.p: In hesitant fuzzy decision making problems, the experts assign exact values for the membership of x in a HFS M. In reality, the membership degrees of a certain element x to M are not necessarily real numbers. They may be a range of values belonging to [0, 1]. To deal with such cases, Chen et al. [6] introduced the concept of interval-valued hesitant fuzzy set (IVHFS), which is a generalization of HFS. This generalization is similar to that encountered in intuitionistic fuzzy environments, where the concept of intuitionistic fuzzy set has been extended to that of interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy set.
div.formula: h rðjÞL e M ðx i Þ ¼ inf h rðjÞ e M ðx i Þ; h rðjÞU e M ðx i Þ ¼ sup h rðjÞ e M ðx i Þ; 1 6 i 6 n; 1 6 j 6 l x i :
div.p: Similar to the previous results obtained for HFSs based on the relationship between information measures, the same can be achieved for IVHFSs.

To develop the relationship between information measures for IVHFSs, the following concepts under interval-valued hesitant fuzzy environment are introduced. Here, the score function of a IVHFS, denoted by Score(Á), is defined as Hereafter, for notational convenience, e M ¼ f½k; kg denotes the IVHFS e M ¼ fhx; ½k; kijx 2 Xg, where k is a fixed real number.
div.formula: Scoreð e MÞ ¼ 1 n X n i¼1 1 l x i X lx i j¼1 h rðjÞL e M ðx i Þ þ h rðjÞU e M ðx i Þ2
div.p: Since the properties of distance measure, similarity measure and entropy for IVHFSs are the same as those for HFSs, there is no need to repeat them here and the reader is referred to Definitions 2.3, 2.4, 2.5.
Drawing on the hesitant distances introduced by ( 2) and ( 3), the interval-valued hesitant distances are defined as follows:
Given two IVHFSs e M and e N; h
div.formula: rðjÞ e M ðx i Þ ¼ h rðjÞL e M ðx i Þ; h rðjÞU e M ðx i Þ h i and h rðjÞ e N ðx i Þ ¼ h rðjÞL e N ðx i Þ; h rðjÞU e N ðx i Þ h i denote the jth largest inter- vals in h e M ðx i Þ and h e N ðx i Þ, respectively.
div.p: Now, the following definitions are considered:
The interval-valued hesitant normalized Hamming distance
div.formula: d ivhnh ðM; NÞ ¼ 1 n X n i¼1 1 2l x i X lx i j¼1 h rðjÞL M ðx i Þ À h rðjÞL N ðx i Þ þ h rðjÞU M ðx i Þ À h rðjÞU N ðx i Þ 2 4 3 5 ;ð12Þ
div.p: The generalized hybrid interval-valued hesitant weighted distance
div.formula: d ghivhw ðM; NÞ ¼ X n i¼1 w i 1 2l x i X lx i j¼1 h rðjÞL M ðx i Þ À h rðjÞL N ðx i Þ k þ h rðjÞU M ðx i Þ À h rðjÞU N ðx i Þ k 0 @ 2 4 þmax j h rðjÞL M ðx i Þ À h rðjÞL N ðx i Þ k ; h rðjÞU M ðx i Þ À h rðjÞU N ðx i Þ k & '!1 k ; k > 0;ð13Þ
div.p: where w i (i = 1,2,. . . , n) is the weight of the element x i with w i 2 [0, 1] and
div.formula: P n i¼1 w i ¼ 1.
div.p: Please cite this article in press as: B. Farhadinia

div.p: , Information measures for hesitant fuzzy sets and interval-valued hesitant fuzzy sets, Inform. Sci. (2013), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ins.2013.03.034
Note that when IVHFSs reduce to HFSs, the above set of distances becomes the same as that given by ( 2) and (3), which indicates the consistency of these two sets of distances.

div.head: Relationship between information measures for IVHFSs
div.p: Proceeding in a way similar to the HFS case, one can easily prove the following theorems. ;

div.head: Clustering algorithms for HFSs and IVHFSs
div.p: Inspired by the hesitant fuzzy clustering algorithm proposed by Chen et al. [6], which involves the correlation coefficient of HFSs, we first develop an algorithm to do clustering under hesitant fuzzy environments by the use of the similarity measure of HFSs. Then, this algorithm is extended to the case of IVHFSs.

Definition 5.1. Let A j (j = 1,2,. . . , m) be m HFSs, and C = [n ij ] mÂm be a similarity matrix, where n ij = S(A i , A j ) denotes the similarity measure of two HFSs A i and A j and satisfies: (1) 0
div.formula: 6 n ij 6 1, i, j = 1,2,. . . , m; (2) n ii = 1, i = 1,2,. . . , m; (3) n ij = n ji , i, j = 1,2,. . . , m. Definition 5.2. Let C = [n ij ] mÂm be a similarity matrix, if C 2 ¼ C C ¼ ½ c n ij mÂm , then C 2 is called a composition matrix of C,
div.p: where c n ij ¼ max k fminfn ik ; n kj gg; i; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; m.
The process of proving the following theorems is the same as that of theorems derived by Xu et al. [34] and therefore it is not necessary to be repeated here.
Theorem 5.1. Let C = [n ij ] mÂm be a similarity matrix. Then, for any non-negative integers m 1 and m 2 , the composition matrix
div.formula: C m 1 þm 2 ¼ C m 1 C m
! C 2 ! C 4 ! Á Á Á ! C 2 k ! Á Á Á,
div.p: there must exist a positive integer k such that C
div.formula: 2 k ¼ C 2 kþ1
div.p: , and C 2 k is also called an equivalent similarity matrix.
Definition 5.4. Let C = [n ij ] mÂm be an equivalent similarity matrix. Then,
div.formula: C k ¼ n k ij h i mÂm is said to be the k-cutting matrix of C if n k ij ¼ 0; n ij < k; 1; n ij P k; & i; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; m;
div.p: and k is the confidence level with k 2 [0, 1].
We now present an algorithm for clustering HFSs as follows.
Algorithm 5.1 (HFS clustering algorithm involving the similarity measure).

Step 1. Let {A 1 , A 2 , . . ., A m } be a set of HFSs in X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . ., x n }. Using the similarity measure given by Theorem 3.3.1, one can calculate the similarity measure degrees of the HFSs, and then construct a similarity matrix C = [n ij ] mÂm , where
div.formula: n ij = S d (A i , A j ).
div.p: Step 2. The process of building the composition matrices is repeated until it holds that
div.formula: C ! C 2 ! C 4 ! . . . ! C 2 k ¼ C 2 ðkþ1Þ ;
div.p: which implies that C 2 k is the equivalent similarity matrix.

Step 3. For simplicity, the notation C is used again to denote the equivalent similarity matrix, which was attained in Step 2. Then for a confidence level k, a k-cutting matrix C k ¼ n k ij h i mÂm is constructed using Definition 5.4 to classify the HFSs A j (j = 1,2,. . . , m). If all elements of the ith line (column) in C k are the same as the corresponding elements of the jth line (column) in C k , then the HFSs A i and A j are of the same type. By using this principle, all these m HFSs A j (j = 1,2,. . ., m) can be classified. Now, a real example adapted from Chen et al. [6] is employed to demonstrate how well the proposed clustering algorithm based on HFSs performs.

Example 5.1 (See [6] ). Software evaluation and classification is an increasingly important problem in any sector of human activity. Industrial production, service provision and business administration depend heavily on software which is becoming more and more complex and expensive. To support the production of software in a computer-integrated manufacturing (CIM) environment, a case tool has to be selected from the ones offered on the market. CIM software typically has responsibility for production planning, production control and monitoring. For more accurate evaluation of different types of CIM softwares A i (i = 1,2,. . . , 7) on the market, the clustering technique is applied to them according to four attributes: x 1 : functionality, x 2 : usability, x 3 : portability, and x 4 : maturity. Inviting the experts with different backgrounds and levels of knowledge, skills, experience and personality, etc. to make such an evaluation will lead to a difference in the evaluation information. To clearly reflect the differences of the opinions of different experts, the evaluation data are represented by the HFSs and listed in Table 1.
Using Algorithm 5.1, the above-mentioned clustering problem is now solved as the following steps illustrate:
div.formula: C 4 ¼
div.p: Step 3. Now, to proceed with an equivalent similarity matrix, consider only the equivalent similarity matrices obtained in Case 1 and Case 2. The following procedure can be similarly carried using the equivalent similarity matrices obtained in Case 3 and Case 4. On the basis of the k-cutting matrices, all possible classifications of A i (i = 1,2,. . . , 7) in Case 1 and Case 2 are achieved, as shown in Tables 2 and3, respectively.
As in the HFS case, a similar algorithm for clustering IVHFSs can be stated as follows:
Algorithm 5.
div.formula: n ij ¼ S d ð e A i ; e A j Þ.
div.p: Step 2. See Algorithm 5.1.
Step 3. See Algorithm 5.1.
Here, another real example adapted from Chen et al. [6] is employed to demonstrate how well the proposed clustering algorithm based on IVHFSs performs.

Example 5.2. See 6). An auto market wants to classify four different cars A i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) into several kinds. Six attributes with the same weight vector are taken into account, including: x 1 : fuel economy, x 2 : friction degree, x 3 : price, x 4 : comfort,

x 5 : design, and x 6 : safety, which are denoted by X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x 6 }. The evaluation information of each car provided by the experts is expressed in the form of IVHFSs. The data in Table 4 represents the satisfaction degree of each alternative to the attribute given by the experts and thus are denoted with interval-valued numbers within [0, 1].

Using Algorithm 5.2, the above-mentioned clustering problem is solved as the following steps illustrate: The finding results in Cases 3 and 4 are similar to those obtained in Cases 1 and 2. That is, one can easily show that C 4 = C 2 .

Step 3. Now, to proceed with an equivalent similarity matrix, consider only the equivalent similarity matrices obtained in Case 1 and Case 2. The following procedure can be similarly carried using the equivalent similarity matrices obtained in Case 3 and Case 4. On the basis of the k-cutting matrices, all possible classifications of A i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) in Case 1 and Case 2 are achieved, as shown in Tables 5 and6, respectively.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, a mutual transformation of the entropy into the similarity measure was introduced for both HFSs and IVHFSs. By the experimental results, it was shown that the proposed entropies for HFSs produce better results than the existing ones. Two illustrative examples, namely HFS and IVHFS clustering problems, were given to show the validity and applicability of the proposed information measures. Since the similarity measure and the distance measure of HFSs and IVHFSs are very much important in real life problems such as decision making, clustering, pattern recognition and image processing, the proposed information measures will be very attractive and will have wide applications in many areas.
7. Uncited references [13,18]. Q2

If there are fewer elements in h e M ðxÞ than in h e N ðxÞ, an extension of h e M ðxÞ should be considered optimistically by repeating its maximum element until it has the same length as h e N ðxÞ. div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The author thanks the valuable suggestions from the three anonymous referees and Professor Witold Pedrycz, the editor in chief, for improving the quality of the paper. The author is also very grateful to Professor Dr. M. Xia for her insightful and constructive comments that led to an improved version of this paper.
